name: African Openbill
description: Openbills live up to their name with the jaws of their long beak slightly curved toward each other, touching at the tips but leaving a gap elsewhere. Interestingly, juveniles have normally shaped beaks, with the gap forming only in adulthood.
image_alt: African Openbill, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 64–76 cm, tail length 16–18 cm, wing length 36.5–42 cm, weight 1–1.8 kg
attractions: The unique beak shape is adapted for extracting mollusk bodies from hard shells. Openbills live in permanent pairs and nest in colonies, often with other bird species.
breeding: The first openbill lived briefly in the zoo from 1956–1957, but consistent breeding began in 1996 with a founding pair, producing its first chick in 2011.
